Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2008 08:38PM LilaT wrote: I was originally diagnosed in February 2007 and I have been on a clinical trial since June of this year after being diagnosed with mets to the axillary, mammary nodes, and some small nodules in the lungs.  For a while the tumors shrank.  The one in the chest was not even visible on the CT I had two months ago.  This week I had a CT scan after having shoulder pain for a week.  The scan showed a mets to a rib that caused a fracture, plus progression in the chest and other areas.  Unfortunately, the chemo I've been on is no longer effective.  I'll have radiation on the rib for the next three weeks and then a new clinical trial starting in January.  This development was very disheartening, however I am very encouraged by the posts on this forum.  I am by no means ready to give into this disease and I have a strong faith in God.  Thanks for the posts about folks who are still going strong in spite of the obstacles this disease throws in their path.  Keep them coming!  Blessings to all, Lila

Posts.Content: LilaT wrote: Hello all, I felt it was important to pass this information along.  This cancer can certainly throw us some curve balls, I'm sure we all agree.   I started on Xeloda in January and finished my first two-week cycle. I had seen an ortho doc for a sore foot that I'd had since December.  He took x-rays which were normal and put me in a cast boot for 4 weeks saying I had some tendonitiis.  The ankle just got worse and after 3 weeks in the boot I could not longer bear weight on it without excruciated pain.  Finally the doc ordered an MRI and blood work and discovered a big tumor at the base of the tibia.  He was shocked as his words to me in the beginning were, "Don't worry, it's not the cancer.  It NEVER spreads below the knee or elbow."   My onc said the same thing when I told him my foot hurt and his reaction to the news on Tuesday was equally as shocked. He said this is an extremely rare thing and most docs go their whole careers and never see bc go below the knee.  I never saw doctors and staff move so fast to get things done and get treatment started.  I'll be getting 10 rads on the ankle and then start a new chemo which is yet to be determined after a PET-CT on Monday.  To complicate things more, I also found a lump in my good breast that wasn't there a week ago.  And my spleen has become enlarged and painful like there's no room for it under my ribs.  I'll be relieved to see the results of the scan.  Needless to say, Xeloda didn't work for me.   Please listen to your bodies and remember anything is possible.  I don't mean live in fear, just pay attention and get things checked out.  This disease is full of surprises.   Love and prayers, Lila Dx 2/14/2007, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 1/6 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
